title: Distinct var metavariables
content: The closed formula ` A. x A. y x = y ` approximately means that the var metavariables ` x ` and ` y ` represent the same variable v_i. In a domain with at most one object, however, this formula is always true, hence the "approximately" in the previous sentence.

blocks.name: bj-hbaeb2
blocks.content: Biconditional version of a form of ~ hbae with commuted quantifiers, not requiring ~ ax-11 . (Contributed by BJ, 12-Dec-2019.) (Proof modification is discouraged.)
blocks.origin:
thm bj-hbaeb2(setvar s0, setvar s1, setvar s2) {
  |- wb(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s0, wal(s2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
} = {
  impbii(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s0, wal(s2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))))
  axc4i(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)), wal(s2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  pm2.61ii(wi(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))), wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s0))), wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1))))
  syl7(wn(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s0)))), wn(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1)))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  sp(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  axc9(s2, s0, s1)
  axc11r(s2, s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  syl5(wal(s2, wceq(cv(s2), cv(s1))), wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  pm2.43i(wal(s0, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wal(s1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))))
  axc11(s0, s1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  axc11r(s2, s1, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  alimi(s0, wal(s2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1))), wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
  sp(s2, wceq(cv(s0), cv(s1)))
}

blocks.name: bj-hbaeb
blocks.content: Biconditional version of ~ hbae . (Contributed by BJ, 6-Oct-2018.) (Proof modification is discouraged.)

blocks.name: bj-hbnaeb
blocks.content: Biconditional version of ~ hbnae (to replace it?). (Contributed by BJ, 6-Oct-2018.)

blocks.name: bj-dvv
blocks.content: A special instance of ~ bj-hbaeb2 . A lemma for distinct var metavariables. Note that the right-hand side is a closed formula (a sentence). (Contributed by BJ, 6-Oct-2018.)
